title: How did William the Conqueror's family get the name Plantagenet? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Plantagenets weren’t really the family of William the Conquerer, they were the senior branch of the House of Anjou that came to rule England and Normandy via matrilineal succession. William the Conquerer’s family was the house of Normandy comprised of the male-line descendants of Hrofr the Walker (Rollo). William conquered England and later died leaving a great succession crisis. William’s oldest son Robert rebelled against his father, and as punishment William used a weird loophole in common succession practises at the time to give Normandy to Robert but leave England to William Rufus. William Rufus never married or had children (some historians suspect he was gay) and when William died in a hunting accident (or assassination) his younger brother Henry took the throne. Henry conquered Normandy and locked Robert in a tower and Robert’s son ended up dying without having children. Henry was the only male line descendant of William still alive, and he famously fathered over a dozen bastards. Henry only had two legitimate children though, William and Matilda/Maud. William died in a shipwreck and Matilda was married first to the Holy Roman Emperor (they had no children together) and then to the son of the Count of Anjou. The son of the Count of Anjou was Geoffrey the Beautiful. Geoffrey was given the nickname Plantagenet because he often wore a planta genista flower. After a period of civil war in England called the Anarchy, Geoffrey and Matilda’s son Henry became king of England and the dynasty he founded was named the Plantagenet dynasty. Geoffrey’s father Fulk V of Anjou was the Count of Anjou before Geoffrey, but he abdicated his place as Count to Geoffrey when he remarried. Fulk’s second wife was Queen Melisande of Jerusalem, and their children ended up becoming Kings of Jerusalem. Since House of Anjou had split into two royal dynasties, the senior branch ruled England the junior branch ruled Jerusalem, the name Plantagenet was used to distinguish the senior branch. Henry was William the Conquerer’s great-grandson via William’s son’s daughter, meaning that Henry and William were family but from different houses.

Plantagenet Kings were the richest family in Europe and ruled England and half of France. Their name came from planta genista, the Latin for yellow broom flower, which the Counts of Anjou wore as an emblem on their helmets. The name Plantagenet was originally spelt Plante Genest or Plantegenest and later Plauntegenet or Plantaginet. It originated as a nickname for Count Geoffrey of Anjou, father of King Henry II who ascended the English throne in 1154. This name has traditionally been taken to mean a ‘sprig of broom’, which is an instance of a ‘hairy shoot’. It seems that there was an earlier tradition for such symbolism. Old Aquitanian Gods and Goddesses had the names of plants and animals. This predated the name Plantapilosa of a famous ninth-century Aquitanian duke. Early medieval beliefs were beginning to develop into scholastic writings about man’s vegetable soul with its powers of nutrition, growth and generation when the noble name Plantapilosa led on to the names Plante Genest and de la Planta in neighbouring Anjou. Plantapilosa means ‘hairy shoot’, which seemingly symbolised robust growth and regeneration. The traditional explanation, dating back to 1605, for the Plantagenet name is that Geoffrey Plante Genest William the Conqueror and his heirs down through 1135 were members of this dynasty (Although of the House of Blois and descended from Rollo). After that it was disputed between William's grandchildren, Matilda, whose husband Geoffrey was the founder of the House of Plantagenet, and Stephen of the House of Blois (or Blesevin dynasty) Venables-Vernon -Legh and other lines.

Only one branch of the Conqueror’s family is ever called Plantagenet, that of his granddaughter, Matilda, called Empress Matilda because of her first marriage to the Holy Roman Emperor, Henry V. After Henry’s death in 1125, she remarried, to Geoffrey, Count of Anjou, whose nickname or personal byname was Plantagenet, presumed to be because he used a sprig of broom (planta genesta) as an emblem, although no one knows for sure. Their son became King Henry II of England, and all subsequent kings until 1485 were his direct male line descendants. These kings, from Henry II to Richard III, are often referred to as Plantagenets. However, it was only from about 1450 on, that any of them is recorded as using it as a surname or family name. English nobility adopted surnames quite early, but for centuries the royals seem to have found no need for one. The first to do so was Richard, Duke of York, founder of the House of York in the Wars of the Roses, the House of York being itself one branch of the House of the Plantagenet, and Richard presumably chose that surname to emphasise that he had a direct male line of descent all the way back to Geoffrey of Anjou, and therefore a claim to the throne as good as, or perhaps even better than, the Lancastrian (but in this sense equally Plantagenet) King Henry VI.

The name wasn't used in William's time. It came later, in the 12th century, as a nickname for Geoffrey, Count of Anjou. It comes from “planta geneste", a shrubby wild plant known in English today as broom, which has long green stems with small leaflets and lots of yellow flowers. It's possible that Geoffrey wore sprigs of it as a kind of badge, but nobody really knows for sure. If you visit the Richard III Centre in Leicester, the modern museum framed around the discovery of Richard's burial place a few years ago, in the courtyard you may notice a broom plant growing, next to a white rose, which I think is probably City of York. The white rose stands for Richard as the last Yorkist King, and the broom for his identity as the last Plantagenet King. House of Plantagenet - Wikipedia

William’s great-grandson, Henry II was the first Plantagenet king. He took the name because of his father’s habit of wearing a certain flower in his hat. Geoffrey V, Count of Anjou always wore a sprig of yellow broom blossom, whose scientific name is planta genista, known in french as plantagenêt. It still grows in very dry areas in Anjou today.

In 1120, William the Conqueror’s granddaughter, Empress Mathilde, married Geoffroy V, count of Anjou, and their son was Henry II of England. (Mathilde was the daughter of William’s youngest son, Henry Beauclerc). One of Geoffroy’s epithets was Plantagenet, as he had the habit of wearing a sprig of the planta genista flower in his hat. However, referring to most of the descendants of Mathilde and Geoffroy as Plantagenets is largely a creation of historians. The first descendant of their’s to also use that name was Richard, 3rd Duke of York (father of Edward IV and Richard III) to show off his royal descent from both of his parents.

I don’t think William the Conqueror's family got the name Plantagenet. The Norman kings included the following rulers: William I (the Conqueror): 1066–1087William II (Rufus): 1087–1100Henry I (Beauclerc): 1100–1135Stephen: 1135–1154Matilda (Maude): 1141 Henry Plantagenet, count of Anjou, succeeded Stephen as Henry II in 1154. As the first of the Angevin kings, Henry II was a European ruler rather than an English king because of the size of his empire and the fact that he was the richest prince in Europe at the time of his ascension to the throne. The Plantagenet rulers were Henry II: 1154–1189Richard I (Lionheart): 1189–1199John: 1199–1216Henry III: 1216–1272Edward I (Longshanks): 1272–1307Edward II: 1307–1327Edward III: 1327–1377Richard II: 1377–1399 Norman and Plantagenet Kings of England

William the Conquerer was succeeded by William II (son) William II was succeeded by Henry I (brother) Henry I’s only sone predeceased him. His only child was Matilda. Her Second Husband and the father of her children was Geoffrey Plantagenet, Count of Anjou Matilda was to be Queen regnant, but the royal council was convinced by her first cousin, Stephen, to give the throne to him. This started a civil war called the “The Anarchy” Eventually Stephen’s only son passed and made peace with Matilda where by her oldest son became Stephan’s heir. Henry Plantagenet as Henry II.

William the Conqueror did not have the family name Plantagenet. It became the family name of the users of England when Henry II became king was the first King to have this name . He was the son of Geoffrey Plantagenet of Anjou who married the Empress Matilda ( she was the granddaughter of William the conqueror )

William’s granddaughter Matilda married Geoffrey, Count of Anjou, whose nickname was Plantagenet, after the sprig of yellow broom blossom he wore in his hat. When Matilda and Geoffrey’s son became King Henry II of England, he continued to use the name Plantagenet. So did his children.
Matilda, daughter of Henry 1 and grandaughter of William married Geoffrey Plantagenent. Their son succeeded to the throne as Henry ll founding the royal Plantagenents
